titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Phyllis Diller papers, 1934-2011 LSC.1893
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ben Sher in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Megan Hahn Fraser, August 2011; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-08 14:49:31 -0700.

did.abstract: This collection includes business papers, correspondence, sheet music, media, and memorabilia from the private collection of comedian and actress Phyllis Diller. Diller broke ground as one of the first and most prominent woman comedians through her stand-up act, films, television appearances, books, and records. Post-retirement in 2002, Diller wrote an autobiography titled Like a Lampshade in a Whorehouse: My Life in Comedy (2005), turned her hobby of drawing and painting into another career, and has continued to make appearances on television and in film.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

Boxes 72, 73 & 76 shelved in Range 22, B-level stacks. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Ben Sher in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Megan Hahn Fraser, August 2011.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Phyllis Ada Driver was born on July 17, 1917 in Lima, OH. She studied at the Sherwood Music Conservatory in Chicago, IL for three years, beginning in fall 1934. She married Sherwood Anderson Diller, and the couple and their children moved from Ypsilanti, MI to Alameda, CA in 1945. Diller began her career as writer and women's editor for the San Leandro News-Observer. From June 1951 to 1954, Diller's jobs included: head of newspaper and radio ad copy in the advertising office of Kahn's, a department store in Oakland, CA; copywriter, publicist, and continuity girl at the radio station KROW in Oakland, CA; and, finally, director of promotion and merchandising at KSFO radio in San Francisco, CA. Her copywriting was distinguished by its comedic flair.

Diller performed in several small and semi-professional venues before getting a lengthy gig at The Purple Onion, a nightclub in San Francisco, CA in March 1955. Following this successful run, she gave opening performances at The Purple Onion in Los Angeles, CA in summer 1956. In Los Angeles, Diller made her first national television appearance as a contestant on the NBC game show You Bet Your Life, hosted by Groucho Marx. Thereafter, she toured the country, performing in major nightclubs such as Mister Kelley's in Chicago, IL, The Blue Angel and The Bon Soir in New York, NY (where she worked with a young Barbra Streisand), The Crescendo in Los Angeles, CA, and The Fontainebleau in Miami Beach, FL. Diller's stand-up act pushed the envelope by lampooning women's roles in the 1950s and 1960s. In particular, she broke from the tradition set by male comedians who complained about their wives by creating a fictional husband, the ne'er-do-well Fang.

Around 1958, Diller made the first of many appearances on The Tonight Show and The Jack Paar Show, the latter for which she eventually became a writer. These appearances brought her heightened success, and led to her discovery by Bob Hope. Diller worked with Hope for decades, performing with him on 23 television specials, in the feature films Boy, Did I Get a Wrong Number! (1960), Eight on the Lam (1967), and The Private Navy of Sgt. O'Farrell (1968), and as part of his USO troupe in Vietnam in 1966. Diller's film work from this period also includes Splendor in the Grass (1962) and voice work in the Rankin/Bass animated film Mad Monster Party (1967). Beginning in the 1960s, Diller became a household name through many TV appearances featuring her stand-up act. She also starred in two short-lived TV series, the half-hour sitcom The Pruitts of Southhampton (later titled The Phyllis Diller Show, 1966-67) and the musical variety show The Beautiful Phyllis Diller Show (1968). From 1961-1970, Diller recorded five albums and published four books. She concluded the 1960s with her Broadway debut in Hello Dolly!

Recent film roles include voice work in Disney's A Bug's Life (1998) and the documentary The Aristocrats (2005). Recent television work includes recurring roles on the series Titus (2001-02), 7th Heaven (1999-2003), The Bold and the Beautiful (1999-2004), and The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius (2002-2004).

In May 1971, Diller drew upon her training as a pianist and made her debut in a concert with Pittsburgh Pops, initiating 10 years of work as a concert pianist. In the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, Diller continued frequent appearances on the stage and screen, and became known as one of the first celebrities to proudly admit to having had plastic surgery.

In 2002, Diller retired from stand-up comedy work. Her final performance, at the Suncoast Hotel in Las Vegas, NV, is captured in the documentary Good Night, We Love You (2006). Post-retirement, Diller wrote an autobiography titled Like a Lampshade in a Whorehouse: My Life in Comedy (2005), turned her hobby of drawing and painting into another career, and has continued to make appearances on television and in film.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence (1969-2010, bulk 2005-2010); contracts and itineraries related to various stand-up, film, and television appearances; books of jokes and gags by Diller and other writers (dated 1964-1988); sheet music from Diller's time at Sherwood Music Conservatory, from her TV series The Beautiful Phyllis Diller Show (1968), and from other performances; extensive clippings from magazines and periodicals (dated 1957-2011, bulk 1992-2007); a representative wig and costume; filmed performances and television appearances (mostly on 16mm and 35mm); Diller's published books and record albums; playbills, programs and pamphlets for shows that Diller starred in or attended; and ephemera and souvenirs from Diller's career.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Correspondence
Job Folders and Other Activities
Jokes and Gags
Photographs
Sheet Music
Clippings
Publications
Playbills and programs
Ephemera and souvenirs
Media
Costumes

Three of the original binders can be found in box 71.

did.unittitle: "Phyllis Diller's Old Music from Sherwood Music School Days and Alameda"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains sheet music from Diller's three years at Sherwood Music Conservatory in Chicago, IL (1934-1938?) and Alameda, CA (1945-approx. 1956). In Alameda, Diller began writing, performing, and eventually touring with her comedy. Subseries includes mostly published classical music and standards. Of particular interest are workbooks from some of Diller's courses at Sherwood Music School.

scopecontent.p: Songs include: "Diller Opening," "Love Story," and "Wives and Lovers."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials from files marked "L.P. File" and "Record." It is unclear which of Diller's released albums (if any) are related to these materials. It is most likely that they relate to her album "Born to Sing" (released by Columbia in 1970), as this is Diller's only released album that contains songs. Folders include sheet music, written and typed lyrics (for songs including "Dancing in the Street," "With a Little Help from My Friends," and "Ticket to Ride,") memos and notes, song lists, lighting and sound requirements for a live performance, and occasional drawings on the margins of papers (presumably by Diller). Some materials are printed on the back of stationary from the radio station KROW, where Diller began her career as a copywriter in 1952. The stationery includes copy from this period, possibly written by Diller. These folders were originally housed with Diller's sheet music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Folders include sheet music, written and typed lyrics (for songs including "Dancing in the Street," "With a Little Help from My Friends," and "Ticket to Ride,") memos and notes, song lists, and lighting and sound requirements for a live performance. Some materials are printed on the back of stationery from the radio station KROW, where Diller began her career as a copywriter in 1952. The stationery includes copy from this period, possibly written by Diller.

did.unittitle: "The Beautiful Phyllis Diller Show" TV series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sheet music for "The Beautiful Phyllis Diller Show," Diller's variety series which ran for one season on NBC in 1968. Folders are organized by episode. When possible, numbers from episodes have been placed together in chronological order within the series. However, sometimes episodes are placed out of chronological order and/or broken up, maintaining the organizational structure of the original collection and allowing sheet music of different sizes to be housed in appropriate boxes. Scope and content notes inform the reader when the music from an episode is broken up within the series, and in which boxes and folders the remaining music from that episode can be found. All songs contained in each folder are listed in scope and content notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unlabeled sheet music from various periods in Diller's career. Series contains a small amount of handwritten sheet music presumably written for Diller's live performances and television appearances (contained in folders 1-4), and a substantial amount of pre-published sheet music from various periods. Notable songs include "Phyllis' Theme" by Ed Robards; "Firestone Theme Song/Theme Song--Phyllis Diller"; "Spinning Song" by F. Mendelssohn; "The Ghoul-Friend" by Murray Grand and June Carroll; and "Phyllis Fugue," written by Diller in 1937. Pre-published sheet music mostly consists of standards from the American songbook (i.e. "Happiness Is A Thing Called Joe" by E.Y. Harburg and Harold Arlen and "These Foolish Things Remind Me of You" by Holt Marvlel, Jack Strachey, and Harry Link), popular American songs (i.e. "New York, New York" by Kander and Ebb; "The Sound of Silence" by Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel), opera music (i.e. Puccini's "La Boheme"), and classical music.

scopecontent.p: Undated clippings labeled "miscellaneous." Includes clips from circa 1960 through the 1990s and 2000s (most clippings appear to be from the latter decades).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes press kit for "The Best of Broadway Presents: The Phyllis Diller Show" (Diller's first television special, different from her sitcom of the same name). See also: Boxes 29, 30, and 48 in the "Sheet Music" series (which contain sheet music that was likely from this special).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Mayor Lewis Brown, Jr.'s proclamation of "Phyllis Diller Day" in San Francisco, CA; press materials from early stage and television performances in the 1950s; a signed check by George Gershwin; "Family Guy" trading card; press material for Phyllis Diller's Original Recipe Chili.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Poster for Phyllis Diller's 81st birthday celebration and screening of the film "The Private Navy of Sergeant O'Farrell," co-starring Bob Hope. The event took place at Akebono Theatre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Only in Hollywood" TV special, which aired on E! Entertainment Television. Labeled: Dub: 11/5/97, Total running time: 60:00. The program was sent to Diller by Jonah Borris at E! Entertainment Television, and includes a note from him. Format: VHS cassette.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A recording of Aileen E. Smith's song "Diller," a song about Diller set to the tune of Michael Jackson's "Thriller." The package contains a letter from Smith and lyrics to the song.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Diller's yellow straw hat with attached matching flowers and leaves, used on various tours. Housed in a clear hatbox. Hatboxes were specially ordered by Diller's daughter and assistant, Stephanie Waldron, so that Diller could display hats easily.
